rdf:Alt.rdf:li: {\rtf1 (ethereal music)}
{\rtf1 So in this lab, basically\par what we're dealing with}
{\rtf1 is we're trying to\par catch abnormal activity,}
{\rtf1 or events of interest, using\par nothing but Windows logs.}
{\rtf1 Specifically, there's a lot of things}
{\rtf1 you can catch (laughs) with Windows.}
{\rtf1 You're going to catch command and control.}
{\rtf1 You can catch unauthorized USBs.}
{\rtf1 You can catch new user\par accounts, persistent mechanisms,}
{\rtf1 pretty much anything that's been done}
{\rtf1 'cause it's all in the endpoint.}
{\rtf1 So one of the most important\par things you can collect}
{\rtf1 on a Windows map or LENOX blocks are}
{\rtf1 the endpoint operating\par system logs themselves.}
{\rtf1 So what we're going to do,\par is go through a scenario.}
{\rtf1 We're going to first map\par out what users to SIDs}
{\rtf1 because even though we have\par a lot of enterprise names,}
{\rtf1 sometimes there are certain\par log sources that don't}
{\rtf1 map the user's SID to\par its actual user name,}
{\rtf1 and you and I are used to\par dealing with user names,}
{\rtf1 not SID numbers, so I'm just\par going to show you real quickly}
{\rtf1 how we can map those.}
{\rtf1 The logs we're looking at,\par hopefully your enterprise SIM}
{\rtf1 automatically does this for you.}
{\rtf1 Newer versions of NXLog,\par which is what I've used}
{\rtf1 for this lab, would've\par automatically done this for me,}
{\rtf1 but I've kept the lab as\par is because I've still seen}
{\rtf1 an enterprise SIMS that\par while most log sources}
{\rtf1 still have the SID to user translated,}
{\rtf1 some of them still don't, and here's what}
{\rtf1 we're going to show how to do that.}
{\rtf1 Then we're going to try and figure out}
{\rtf1 what system's been compromised,}
{\rtf1 and did they have administrative access?}
{\rtf1 What user account was compromised?}
{\rtf1 And then we're going to try\par to find the name pipe attack,}
{\rtf1 the privilege escalation involved,}
{\rtf1 and we're going to see where they created}
{\rtf1 a local user account, and then add it}
{\rtf1 to the administrator's account,}
{\rtf1 and we're going to walk through this.}
{\rtf1 For this, we're going\par to be using a dashboard}
{\rtf1 for lab 3.2, so -43.2,}
{\rtf1 Windows events to monitor.}
{\rtf1 In this dashboard, I\par kind of just put things}
{\rtf1 in different spots.}
{\rtf1 A lot of this is what\par you would want to have}
{\rtf1 automated alerts for, but\par again, I'm trying to teach}
{\rtf1 the process, and then\par you go and map it out}
{\rtf1 however you see fit.}
{\rtf1 So in here, we have new service creations,}
{\rtf1 which we have three of them.}
{\rtf1 One looks like a random service name,}
{\rtf1 new scheduled tasks, logs being cleared,}
{\rtf1 new local users being added.}
{\rtf1 We see Help Desk 31337,\par or a leak on the CFO box.}
{\rtf1 We see monitored events by host name.}
{\rtf1 The inner circle is the host.}
{\rtf1 The outer circle are\par the suspicious events,}
{\rtf1 so like logs being cleared,\par member added to the local group,}
{\rtf1 new local user, new service creation.}
{\rtf1 The other box had the new scheduled task}
{\rtf1 and new service creation.}
{\rtf1 So kind of different ways\par of looking at the data,}
{\rtf1 and I see members added\par to the local group,}
{\rtf1 and of course, my safe search.}
{\rtf1 So this is what we're dealing with.}
{\rtf1 First thing I want to do here,}
{\rtf1 is I want to map out the SIDS.}
{\rtf1 If you had a SID, but you\par didn't know the user name,}
{\rtf1 how difficult is it to figure it out?}
{\rtf1 Well, really all you have\par to do is search for the SID.}
{\rtf1 So here I'm grabbing one\par of them that's in the list.}
{\rtf1 So I've got a SID here,\par a SID here, SID here.}
{\rtf1 We're going to go ahead and map these out}
{\rtf1 starting with this S-1521 and up to 1001.}
{\rtf1 Hit search, and we can see here.}
{\rtf1 Let's let that finish, and\par if we were to scroll down}
{\rtf1 and look at the logs,}
{\rtf1 we also could look at the visualizations.}
{\rtf1 This first one is related to me (laughs).}
{\rtf1 So the first SID that we're\par searching for is J. Henderson.}
{\rtf1 We'd write that down.}
{\rtf1 We'd then look for the next one.}
{\rtf1 This will be 1115.}
{\rtf1 You'd do the same thing.}
{\rtf1 Paste that in there, search,}
{\rtf1 so the one ending in 1115.}
{\rtf1 We look at this.}
{\rtf1 This would've been P. Dodson.}
{\rtf1 All right, another one.}
{\rtf1 Oh, I could've copied it there.}
{\rtf1 Then we have S1518.}
{\rtf1 I know what that one is.}
{\rtf1 It's system, just to verify and correct.}
{\rtf1 There's S1518.}
{\rtf1 Let that finish over here.}
{\rtf1 DCO1, DC01 dollar sign,}
{\rtf1 You'd see different system names down here}
{\rtf1 if we were to keep searching.}
{\rtf1 The reason is shows up as the computer}
{\rtf1 is 'cause it's the special\par Gotham system account}
{\rtf1 for that computer.}
{\rtf1 The reason I knew that system is S-1-5-18}
{\rtf1 is always local system.}
{\rtf1 It's kind of the root\par account on a Windows box,}
{\rtf1 and it's always that SID, so that one}
{\rtf1 I just kind of knew from memory.}
{\rtf1 So there's that one.}
{\rtf1 Then we have more, I believe.}
{\rtf1 It's the one 1007.}
{\rtf1 Search for that one.}
{\rtf1 There we go.}
{\rtf1 Scroll down and we see.}
{\rtf1 It's still searching.}
{\rtf1 There we go.}
{\rtf1 This one is going to be related}
{\rtf1 to the new user being created\par at this Help Desk 311337}
{\rtf1 You could go through and\par start expanding some of these.}
{\rtf1 Let me see, user account was enabled.}
{\rtf1 Which user account?}
{\rtf1 Help Desk 31 and 337.}
{\rtf1 You could expand different\par logs and figure this out.}
{\rtf1 So if you had to do SID\par translation, and I hope you don't,}
{\rtf1 I've just seen it time and time again,}
{\rtf1 just search for the SID and\par find some logs related to it,}
{\rtf1 and write down what that user name is,}
{\rtf1 so that's all that is.}
{\rtf1 The rest of this lab's more (laughs) fun.}
{\rtf1 So okay, identify the compromised host.}
{\rtf1 So there's two ways of doing this.}
{\rtf1 The easy way is to use the visualization}
{\rtf1 that shows everything all on one,}
{\rtf1 this monitored events by hosting.}
{\rtf1 We have CFO and we have ITO three}
{\rtf1 ITO three only has two\par potentially suspicious events,}
{\rtf1 a new service creation,\par and a new scheduled task.}
{\rtf1 CFO has four, logs have been cleared,}
{\rtf1 members added to local\par group, a new local user,}
{\rtf1 and new service creation.}
{\rtf1 Just from looking at how many\par of this suspicious events,}
{\rtf1 and what they are, CFO's a prime candidate}
{\rtf1 for the one being compromised.}
{\rtf1 If we wanted to drill into these,}
{\rtf1 we could start looking at the\par surrounding visualizations.}
{\rtf1 So let's just see here, so we see CFO,}
{\rtf1 Help Desk 31337, ITO three,\par we see Google update,}
{\rtf1 which is also related to\par the new scheduled task.}
{\rtf1 That's common if you\par install Google Chrome.}
{\rtf1 We see that HHRWA.}
{\rtf1 That's on CFO.}
{\rtf1 All right, so then the question is,}
{\rtf1 if we think that one is,\par when we look at this,}
{\rtf1 the system account is the one\par that created Help Desk 31337.}
{\rtf1 Well, if we think CFO is compromised}
{\rtf1 and system is the one\par that created the help desk}
{\rtf1 based on this visualization,\par how did the CFO box}
{\rtf1 initially get compromised?}
{\rtf1 What user was actually compromised?}
{\rtf1 So one of the things we\par can do to figure this out,}
{\rtf1 is we can simply create\par an ad hoc visualization,}
{\rtf1 seeing what users were\par used on the CFO box.}
{\rtf1 So I'm going to do visualize.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to do a new table.}
{\rtf1 You're not going to save this,}
{\rtf1 this is a manual analysis\par what we're doing here.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to do the user term,}
{\rtf1 and we'll do 10 just to\par see what all accounts}
{\rtf1 are used on this box, and\par I'm going to search for}
{\rtf1 logs related to the user on that box.}
{\rtf1 Let me see, help desk goes to that SID.}
{\rtf1 I don't think I got the right search here.}
{\rtf1 Here we go.}
{\rtf1 There we go.}
{\rtf1 I only want to see things\par related to the host name of CFO,}
{\rtf1 and I don't want to see machine accounts}
{\rtf1 or service accounts for the most part.}
{\rtf1 These SIDs are still system.}
{\rtf1 That's the Paul Dodson account.}
{\rtf1 Here it is.}
{\rtf1 So if we see these are\par the only user accounts,}
{\rtf1 the only actual user user\par on this, is P. Dodson,}
{\rtf1 which is this, so some\par logs have a user name,}
{\rtf1 and his SID, which is still P. Dodson.}
{\rtf1 Knowing this, most likely what occurred}
{\rtf1 is P. Dodson got compromised,\par privilege escalation ensued,}
{\rtf1 and then they became system.}
{\rtf1 So Paul Dodson looks to be\par the user that was compromised.}
{\rtf1 All right, let's go back\par and let's filter in on that}
{\rtf1 new service creation for a second.}
{\rtf1 So we saw that HHRWA,\par random generated demand.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to zoom in on that, and we see,}
{\rtf1 let that search fast come up.}
{\rtf1 There we go, new service\par was installed on the system.}
{\rtf1 Scroll down.}
{\rtf1 We're going to see CNB to\par HC/C echo, the random string}
{\rtf1 into, this is a named pipe in Windows.}
{\rtf1 This is method of doing\par privilege escalation.}
{\rtf1 Which user did this run as?}
{\rtf1 P. Dodson, the standard user account.}
{\rtf1 At the end of this though,\par the service that was created}
{\rtf1 as set to run as local system,}
{\rtf1 and then it was immediately started.}
{\rtf1 So P. Dodson was\par compromised, this named pipe}
{\rtf1 privilege escalation service was created.}
{\rtf1 It was started, than the\par adversary became system,}
{\rtf1 so we can start to track all of this}
{\rtf1 because we have those logs in there.}
{\rtf1 All right, so we've also\par figured out the user}
{\rtf1 that was compromised.}
{\rtf1 We figured out the privileged escalation}
{\rtf1 'cause it was related to the new service.}
{\rtf1 Now which account was added\par to the local administrator?}
{\rtf1 Well, we already found that one}
{\rtf1 because the dashboard is\par literally just looking}
{\rtf1 for some well known common\par things adversaries do.}
{\rtf1 So Help Desk 31337 is\par the user added to the}
{\rtf1 local administrators group.}
{\rtf1 We also see it over here.}
{\rtf1 You could drill down on this.}
{\rtf1 There's multiple ways of doing this.}
{\rtf1 Make sure the search fully submits,}
{\rtf1 and if we were to analyze these,}
{\rtf1 we'd see Help Desk 31337 was added}
{\rtf1 to the local administrators group.}
{\rtf1 So this lab is fairly straightforward}
{\rtf1 because if you know\par what events to collect,}
{\rtf1 monitor, what audit policies to enable,}
{\rtf1 and you're bringing them in,}
{\rtf1 it's actually pretty easy to\par catch some of these attacks.}
{\rtf1 The module we did in 555,\par from start to finish,}
{\rtf1 you catch the adversary in multiple ways.}
{\rtf1 And remember, throughout\par this, as long as one of these}
{\rtf1 was in place and you caught the adversary}
{\rtf1 with one detection technique,\par that's all you needed,}
{\rtf1 but a lot of times they're going\par to trigger multiple things.}
{\rtf1 So make sure you have\par the right audit policies}
{\rtf1 and log collection\par strategy in place to get}
{\rtf1 key endpoint data so that you\par can find events of interest}
{\rtf1 because if you're collecting\par them, it's pretty easy}
{\rtf1 to analyze them and it's very powerful.}
